comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
From "Raids and Rallies" (Ernie O'Malley):
(1921) "Dr Finegan was referring to five officers of the Leitrim brigade - a portion or a column under Seán Connolly from the Longford Brigade - who had been killed by the British on 11 March at Selton Hill, County Leitrim after information of their presence had been given to Thomas Gore-Hickman, the District Inspector of the RIC in Mohill
From: "Rising out: Seán Connolly of Longford (1890-1921)" (Ernie O'Malley, Cormac K. H. O'Malley)
the lorry was the oridinary passing lorry of troops, he went up towards it for it had halted outside of McCullough's gate. A police officer, Thomas Gore-Hickman, the RIC District Inspector in Mohill, got out of a car which was behind the soldiers and walked over to Flynn: 'Did you see any armed men around here', he asked? 'No, I didn't, I was at school all day'...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is young Thomas at home in Clare in 1901's census You can see that his Uncle Thomas is an O'Brien. In the Landed Estates Database, we have the Hickman family of Kilmore House, and a Gore connection: Francis William Gore of Tyredagh assumed the surname of Hickman in 1878. Why? Because: In 1824, Mary Browne, daughter of Edmond and Anne Browne, married Francis Gore and their descendants eventually inherited the Hickman estate by the will of Anne’s brother, Poole Hickman, who died in 1842. He was succeeded by his sister, Letitia Hickman, who held an estate comprised of at least nine townlands in the parishes of Killimer and Kilmurry at the time of Griffith’s Valuation. So Francis Gore married into the Hickman family, and when Francis inherited the Hickman lands, he assumed the name Hickman (a condition of the will, maybe?), and gave just that name in the census of 1901 and 1911 . Thomas evidently felt he should restore the Gore name, as well as double-barrelling with his mothers surname [Edit:]Francis's father was named Francis Gore too, so I'm not sure which of them inherited/changed his name...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Hickman’s eldest son Thomas had joined the Auxialiaries and gained a notorious reputation in the Longford / Roscommon area. In response to the burning of the family homes and businesses of known I.R.A. members by the R.I.C., the I.R.A. had begun arson attacks on the family homes of men who had joined the Black & Tans and the Auxiliaries in both Britain and Ireland. District Inspector Thomas Hickman a member of the R.I.C. Auxiliary Division There are a number of possible motives why Kilmore was burnt; Hickman’s unpopularity, jealousy of Behan as cited by the R.I.C., the use of the house by the British Army, or his son’s membership of the Auxiliaries. On 5 July 1921, Hazelwood House in Quin, another property belonging to Hickman, was burned down by the I.R.A. Hazelwood and its contents were valued at one hundred thousand pounds. Your picture is posted here about half way down. www.warofindependence.info/?page_id=225

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
Most of the descriptions of Gore-Hickman come from accounts of events in Leitrim during the War of Independence. See for example "The Tragedy of Selton Hill" (Leirim Guardian)
(1921) "Unknown to anyone, events leading to the tragedy were already beginning to take shape. Information on their movements was brought to Mohill and was conveyed to District-Inspector Gore-Hickman, a tough and fearless veteran, thorough in his methods and ruthless to match. He phoned immediately to Boyle for the troops.
And a little more about this event during War of Independence (and Gore-Hickman's involvement) here in the Leitrim Observer.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: As Danny notes, it sounds like the IRA took some retribution on the Gore-Hickman family/homestead back in Clare. As Gore-Hickman's father made claims for compensation after the war for the confiscation and destruction of the family home. There's some notes there too about how (this) Gore-Hickman and his brothers all served in the Great War. It's one of those terrible stories about allegiances and retribution that are all too common in that period. The descriptions of Gore-Hickman suggest he wasn't shy of some fairly rough tactics himself though.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Thomas Gore-Hickman, officer, aged 32, was a passenger on the SS Marloch, which sailed from Liverpool on 21st March 1925, bound for St. Johns, N.B. With him were his wife May, aged 30, and their infant son Francis (according to Canadian immigration records, born in England).

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] To be honest I'm not too surprised they left. The Gore-Hickman's were clearly a landed family from Clare - where they'd lived for generations. The extended Gore/Hickman family(s) had several estates in Clare - including at Kilmore where Thomas was likely raised. Records from the 1880s show they had some troubles from the Land League and nationalist neighbours, and the social events (incl. funerals) the family attended suggest a less-than-nationalist leaning for some generations. All the brothers signed-up during the Great War (one not coming home). I imagine Thomas wasn't entirely at ease with the way he saw things going politically on his own return from France (home rule, devolution, etc). He seems to have used his military experience fairly forcefully in several events during the War of Independence. Given all this, the family were effectively burned-out of their properties in Clare. Coupled with the fact that he would've been persona-non-grata in the new order after the war (up to and including being a marked-man for those events in Leitrim), I am not at all surprised to find them heading to England. And on to Canada. There wouldn't have been much to keep a man like Gore-Hickman in Ireland after the war.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I imagine 1919 or 1920 is probably right for the photo date. He wasn't demobbed from the army until after WWI (late 1918, early 1919). I can't imagine a photo like that being taken during the War of Independence, so I'd say it's 1920 alright (maybe +/- 1).

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Thomas's brother Poole Henry (at home in Clare in 1911, a Barrister-at-law) died in 1915 at Gallipoli with the Dublin Fusiliers: Hickman Poole Henry- Captain 7th Bn. Royal Dublin Fusiliers 15/08/1915 35 County Clare Son of Francis William and Elizabeth B. Gore Hickman, of 23, Earlsport Terrace, Dublin. Religion Church of Ireland. Attended Trinity College Dublin BA 1902. Lieutenant September 1914 Captain January 1915.

comment.author: 20727502@N00

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content:
I found a footnote in the Ernie O'Malley book (probably added by editor Cormac O'Malley) about Gore-Hickman after the Selton Hill ambush:
Thomas O'Brien Gore-Hickman (1892-1982), the RIC District Inspector in Mohill was from Co. Clare. After the Selton Hill incident, he immediately left for England and did not return until after the Truce. He emigrated thereafter.
(I am not at all surprised. And all stacks up.)

Clare.  All those families were complicatedly interconnected.

comment.author: 72555039@N00
comment._content: One needs to be careful with these photos. I've seen the Beaslai collection and some of the photos are copies of originals, often poor copies, and annotated, as has been noted, on the reverse. It is not clear where they were originally sourced nor who annotated them. This man, a District Inspector in the RIC, may well be Gore-Hickman, but certain aspects of the photo give me cause to doubt. Firstly, the pose and background suggest an earlier period, whereas Gore-Hickman joined the RIC in early 1920. I would expect the composition and lighting to have been much better; more importantly, he seems to be wearing a cross belt plate with the 'early' style crown, suggesting pre-1901. I can't really make out the crown on the helmet plate. So is it him, or has Beaslai assumed it to be him? I would not be certain. His brother's photo is shown in this link - www.markhams-of-derryguiha.com/id24.html - and you may think there is a certain similarity. Perhaps so, but like any photo of this period, it is worth double checking.

comment.author: 72555039@N00
comment._content: By the way the uniform is 'full dress' pattern and would have been black. The officers 'patrol' jacket - the one you would normally see, would be a dark green.

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/traphill] As you note, and as Carol also hinted-at, I think we do need to take this one with a pinch of low-sodium salt alternative. If this is Gore-Hickman, then it would be ~1920, but everything in the photo (and the patina/frame/tones of the photo itself) would suggest an earlier date. So, interesting as the "investigation" into the (alleged) subject has been, I would also stop short of definitively labelling this one as is advertised. (I guess Carol agrees - which is why the "allegedly" probably remains firmly attached to the title) :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Well look, we have lots of information now on Thomas O'Brien Gore-Hickman, even if it's not he in this photograph. I am happier about an early date based on the photograph itself (especially given [http://www.flickr.com/photos/traphill]'s expert knowledge of the 'early' style crown, suggesting pre-1901), so who knows what will emerge about this one...
